p: In citrus, polyploidy is often associated to a wide range of morphological and physiological changes that are often advantageous under adverse environmental conditions ( Allario et al., 2012; Ruiz et al., 2016a). For instance, citrus tetraploids are shorter and have bigger leaf area ( Allario et al., 2011), have thicker mesophyll cells that have been associated to an increase in internal diffusive resistances to CO 2, thus reducing net photosynthetic rate ( Romero-Aranda et al., 1997), contributing to explain in part the dwarf phenotype observed in tetraploids ( Allario et al., 2011).
